newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary's BUX rallies to new record close.
newsitem.headline: Hungary's BUX rallies to new record close.

text.p: The Hungarian share market rallied to new record levels on Wednesday, bolstered by fresh demand and a strong dollar, traders said.
The BUX index finished at a preliminary 6,870.57 points, up 116.62 points or 1.73 percent. BUX futures were also trading firmer.

"Foreigners already appeared on Tuesday with strong demand at lower prices," said Kalman Schuszter of New York Broker Budapest. "At the same time one should not forget that the dollar has strengthened substantially."
A strong dollar makes the forint, thus Hungarian shares cheaper for foreigners.
Currently the forint trades at 188.11/16 to the dollar, compared to 187.70/75 at opening.
An analyst told Reuters earlier today that fresh capital was flowing in the Hungarian market.

"I think there are probably people taking some profit but at the same time there's much more money coming in," Tommy Erdei, analyst at ABN-AMRO Hoare Govett in Budapest, told Reuters earlier today. He added, however, that he expected some slowdown to come in the coming month.
On Wednesday several stocks hit new record levels before closing a little lower.

Among them was OTP Bank for which an increasing number of foreign funds show demand, Schuszter said. OTP finished at 5,150 forints, up 200, but below an all-time high of 5,220 forints reached during the session.
Hotel firm Danubius benefited from its announcement this morning according to which the privatisation agency APV Rt transferred 1.407 billion forints to it under the 1989 privatisation law.
"This 1.4 billion forint is at least as important as a five billion payout for TVK," Schuszter said.
APV said in late June it was to pay 4.40 billion forints of of privatisation revenue and an additional 842 million of accumulated interest to TVK until June 30.
Elsewhere on the market, garment factory Styl was suspended after a 20.83 percent rally to 1,450 forints.
Heavyweight oil firm MOL closed at 4,185 forints, up 85, in moderate turnover.
